qas.question: Which part of the brain does short-term memory seem to rely on?

answers.text: frontal lobe (especially dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) and the parietal lobe

qas.question: Which part of the brain does long-term memory rely on?
How much information can the hippocampus store?
If the hippocampus doesn't store information what does it do?

answers.text: may be involved in changing neural connections for a period of three months or more after the initial learning.

qas.question: What type of patterns is long-term memory supported by?

plausible_answers.text: frontal lobe (especially dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) and the parietal lobe

qas.question: What two brain lobe regions does long-term memory depend on?
Who had the removal of both of his lobes?
What was removed from Molaison to  improve his attention span?
What part of the brain is not essential for learning new information?

context: Short-term memory is supported by <b4_0>transient<b4_0/> patterns of neuronal communication, dependent on regions of the <a0_0><b5_0>frontal lobe (especially dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) and the parietal lobe<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Long-term memory, on the other hand, is maintained by more stable and permanent changes in neural connections widely spread throughout the brain. The <a1_0><b8_0>hippocampus<b8_0/><a1_0/> is essential (for learning new information) to the consolidation of information from short-term to long-term memory, although it <a2_0>does not<a2_0/> seem to store information itself. Without the hippocampus, new memories are unable to be stored into long-term memory, as learned from patient <b6_0>Henry Molaison<b6_0/> after removal of <b7_0>both his hippocampi<b7_0/>, and there will be a very short attention span. Furthermore, it <a3_0>may be involved in changing neural connections for a period of three months or more after the initial learning.
